subject: Interface YAML:PowerDistribution
commitMessage:
Interface YAML:PowerDistribution

The Power distribution fru is populated as an inventory object.
This interface is to represent the power distribution fru.

The power distribution devices receives voltage from power supply unit and properly distributes/regulates it across other devices,
thereby allowing proper functioning without any effect of over currents or short circuits.

Signed-off-by: Priyanga Ramasamy <priyanga24@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: If04bd2d2f3a04fe6260435d5504a4e128fbc7877

This code needs to be rebased and regenerate-meson reran, if it is still relevant.  I don't really see much documentation on the purpose of this.  Why have an interface with no properties?

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> This code needs to be rebased and regenerate-meson reran, if it is still relevant.  I don't really see much documentation on the purpose of this.  Why have an interface with no properties?

While modelling the inventory, we populate power distribution fru to the inventory objects. So we need this interface to represent it.

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 3:
> While modelling the inventory, we populate power distribution fru to the inventory objects. So we need this interface to represent it.

This is circular logic.  "We want an interface to model X because we want to model X".

Do you have an example of code where this is useful or needed?  I really can't make any judgement call on this in the current state.  A "power distribution device" could just be a resistor tree on a PCB.  Are these really voltage-regulator chips that you're trying to model or something else?

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> > Patch Set 3:
> > While modelling the inventory, we populate power distribution fru to the inventory objects. So we need this interface to represent it.
> 
> This is circular logic.  "We want an interface to model X because we want to model X".
> 
> Do you have an example of code where this is useful or needed?  I really can't make any judgement call on this in the current state.  A "power distribution device" could just be a resistor tree on a PCB.  Are these really voltage-regulator chips that you're trying to model or something else?

This Power distribution fru is present in i2c bus 4 as Fansipan VPD in everest bmc. So we collect the VPD and populate it on dbus. This regulates the voltage and distributes it to other devices.
Uploaded patch set 6: New patch set was added with same tree, parent, and commit message as Patch Set 5.

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 5:
> This Power distribution fru is present in i2c bus 4 as Fansipan VPD in everest bmc. So we collect the VPD and populate it on dbus. This regulates the voltage and distributes it to other devices.

So you have a specific system where you have an entity with an inventory EEPROM and you're calling that a "power distribution fru".  Why is that useful to have as a special free-standing inventory object?  Why isn't an existing Inventory object, like Board or VRM, just as useful?

Boards - we can't use as it represents chassis in some cases.
This power distribution fru is a riser card type and I don't think VRMs will be correct. Can you suggest a better option other than "PowerDistribution" interface yaml or can we go with the same?

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:

> Boards - we can't use as it represents chassis in some cases.

Can you expand on this?  We have a separate element for Chassis, so I don't know why there would be confusion.

> This power distribution fru is a riser card type and I don't think VRMs will be correct. Can you suggest a better option other than "PowerDistribution" interface yaml or can we go with the same?

I still don't really understand what you are trying to accomplish by having a different name.  Is there something achieved by having a name "PowerDistribution"?  I don't think this is very common inventory type, so I can't really see any code triggering off of it.  If there is no code use case then it seems to me we should use a generic element (hence why I was suggesting Board).

In some cases like in bmcweb code the board interface is used to represent chassis. This creates confusion. so there is a plan to remove Board interface.

And the power distribution fru is a riser card type.
So can we have RiserCard interface instead of power distribution interface? this will be more generic.

Patch Set 6:

> In some cases like in bmcweb code the board interface is used to represent chassis. This creates confusion. so there is a plan to remove Board interface.

I talked briefly with Ed and Gunnar on IRC about this and it seems like there is some confusion.  They are moving Boards from Redfish Chassis to Redfish Assembly, but it doesn't seem like that precludes new Boards from being created while that work is on-going.

> And the power distribution fru is a riser card type.
> So can we have RiserCard interface instead of power distribution interface? this will be more generic.

Even RiserCard I don't fully understand the advantage of breaking it apart.  I think we should have a use-case before we create additional sub-types (beyond Board).  I'm not saying we can't break things apart, I just want to make sure we have a reason to do it.  ie. some code is going to consume "SubType" differently from "Board" in a meaningful way.

Ed did say:
> power distribution boards might be treated differently....  In redfish I think they'd show up under the power resources instead of assembly

Can you figure out from the Redfish schemas how this Item would be represented in Redfish?

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> > In some cases like in bmcweb code the board interface is used to represent chassis. This creates confusion. so there is a plan to remove Board interface.
> 
> I talked briefly with Ed and Gunnar on IRC about this and it seems like there is some confusion.  They are moving Boards from Redfish Chassis to Redfish Assembly, but it doesn't seem like that precludes new Boards from being created while that work is on-going.

Correct.  Board will always be represented somewhere, the only thing that's changing in this case is Item.Board is moving from redfish/v1/Chassis/<boardname> to /redfish/v1/Chassis/<mainchassis>/Assemblies/<boardname>

With that said, under the "old" (ie what openbmc currently implements) interpretation of the redfish spec, a PDB would become a Redfish Chassis, with ChassisType=Module.  That's not the best, and ideally we'd have assemblies, but we're not there yet.

> 
> > And the power distribution fru is a riser card type.
> > So can we have RiserCard interface instead of power distribution interface? this will be more generic.

?  A power distribution board is different than a riser card;  It's confusing to me the fluid change in thoughts here.  Can you point to the device you're trying to model?  Is it both?

A power distribution board tends to look like this:
https://parts.metservers.com/00g8cn-dell-poweredge-r320-r420-power-distribution-board

And a Riser card tends to look like this:
https://www.itinstock.com/dell-poweredge-r320-r420-pci-express-x16-usb-riser-card-slot-2-488my-73505-p.asp

If we're going to break down the item interfaces to this level, they are very different things.

> 
> Even RiserCard I don't fully understand the advantage of breaking it apart.  I think we should have a use-case before we create additional sub-types (beyond Board).  I'm not saying we can't break things apart, I just want to make sure we have a reason to do it.  ie. some code is going to consume "SubType" differently from "Board" in a meaningful way.

+1

> 
> Ed did say:
> > power distribution boards might be treated differently....  In redfish I think they'd show up under the power resources instead of assembly
> 
> Can you figure out from the Redfish schemas how this Item would be represented in Redfish?

+1

Abandoned

As per the discussion, the power distribution is not considered as a FRU. So we don't need an interface for it. Abandoning this commit.
Thanks for your valuable time @Patrick Williams @Ed Tanous.
Your signed-off-by appears to be a user id rather than a legal name?  Can you please update?
Done
fix line wraps at 80 characters.
Done

The `./gen/regenerate_meson` needs to be re-ran on this.  The underlying meson generator changed recently and this blob is now outdated (from your simple rebase).  You'll also see CI is failing because it is catching that this blob is out-of-date.
When I re-run ./gen/regenerate_meson, a bunch of meson.build files getting added into my local. Do I need to add all those files to this commit?
Almost certainly not. Are you sure your local copy of the sdbusplus repo is up to date?

sdbusplus repo?
do you mean phosphor dbus interfaces? if yes, then yes it is updated

No.  I mean sdbusplus.

Either:
    1. You are using a meson-subproject to find the sdbusplus code.
    2. You are running in an SDK.

The ./gen/regenerate_meson script looks for the sdbusplus tools in PATH, which might be set up by an SDK, and then looks in subprojects.  Whichever one is being chosen is most likely out of date.
ok. Thanks. Will update my sdk and try re-run
